Award.AwardTitle: Kinetic Mechanisms of DNA Mismatch Repair Proteins
Award.AbstractNarration:
The DNA mismatch repair system (MMR) maintains the integrity of the genome by locating and correcting errors in the double helix. Defects in MMR lead to high levels of mutagenesis; thus there is considerable significance in understanding the mechanism of this critical DNA repair process. The proteins responsible for MMR identify errors such as mismatched base pairs or base insertions/deletions made during DNA replication, and signal excision of the error-containing strand followed by DNA resynthesis. The project studies two essential MMR proteins, MutS, which recognizes the errors in DNA, and MutL, which signals initiation of strand excision. These proteins are highly conserved through evolution, and our research on both prokaryotic (Thermus aquaticus) and eukaryotic (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) MMR proteins will answer fundamental questions about their functions in diverse organisms. Specifically, fluorescence-based transient kinetics methods are being used to (a) measure the conformational dynamics of MutS and DNA during mismatch recognition, (b) examine the actions of MutL during initiation of strand excision, and (c) explore the connections between DNA replication and repair. Findings from this study will provide high-resolution mechanistic data that will complement high-resolution structural data on these proteins and thus increase our understanding of how they work to protect DNA.

Broader Impacts: The broader impact of the project includes teaching and training of students in quantitative biological research and development of professional careers in the life sciences. In addition to graduate students, the PI's group generally has several undergraduates, including under-represented minority students, who are involved in all aspects of the project and often publish their findings in peer-reviewed journal articles. Furthermore, the PI is deeply involved in developing new approaches to incorporate science into the arts, humanities and social sciences curricula at her university. She co-teaches courses with Film Studies faculty (Making the Science Documentary) and Dance faculty (Body Languages-Choreographing Biology), and is currently leading a university-funded "Sciences Across the Curriculum" initiative to support creation of new team-taught courses that present substantive science content and scientific thinking in the context of other disciplines, thereby engaging non-science majors with science in more personally relevant ways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term integrity of genetic information contained in DNA depends on continual correction of errors by the DNA mismatch repair pathway (MMR) in all living organisms. Defects in MMR lead to high levels of mutagenesis, which destabilizes genomic DNA and is associated with inherited disorders such as the Lynch cancer syndrome in humans, underlining the significance of investigating MMR. The focus of the recently completed NSF-funded project was on two MMR proteins: MutS, which identifies mismatched base-pairs in DNA and targets them for repair, and MutL, which takes over from MutS following mismatch recognition and initiates the repair process. At the start of the project, key questions about the mechanisms of action of these proteins related to their dynamic interactions with DNA and with each other, their actions on DNA, and the manner in which they utilize ATP to perform MMR were unresolved. Over the past few years we have been addressing these questions in molecular detail, primarily by using fluorescence-based methods to monitor MutS and MutL activities in solution and on a fast, millisecond time scale. Some of the key results of our transient kinetic studies, which complement results from other investigators who apply different biophysical approaches to the problem, can be summarized as follows: (i) MutS moves on DNA in an ADP-bound dynamic state, which enables the protein to probe the double helix for a mismatched base-pair; (ii) when MutS encounters a mismatch, both the protein and DNA undergo slow changes in conformation leading to an ATP-bound stable MutS-DNA complex (closed-protein/kinked DNA); (iii) this stable complex has a long enough lifetime on the mismatch and the appropriate conformation to interact with MutL and form a larger complex that appears to be localized in the vicinity of the mismatch. These findings have offered new details on how MutS and MutL initiate MMR selectively and efficiently at sites of error in DNA that must be corrected.

The broader impacts of the project included training of several scientists at undergraduate, graduate and post-PhD levels in the disciplines of biochemistry and biophysics. Many of the undergraduates are now either in graduate or medical school, and some graduate students have moved on to independent careers in industry. Complementary educational activities included development of a campus-wide "Science across the Curriculum" initiative that supported new interdisciplinary courses team-taught by faculty from science and non-science disciplines (e.g, computer science/music; environmental studies/government; biology/religion; psychology/english). These courses were aimed at broadening and deepening engagement of non-science majors with science; their success enabled wider acceptance across campus and more institutional support for pedagogical approaches that find and build on complementarity between disparate disciplines and thereby enhance student learning.
